metadata.titleEn: Multi-scale surface flux and meteorological elements observation dataset in the Hai River Basin (Miyun site-automatic weather station) (2008-2010)
metadata.description:
The data set contains observations from the automatic weather station as at 1 solstice, January 2008, on 29 December 2010.The site is located in xinchengzi town, miyun county, Beijing, with orchards (plums and apple trees), corn/bare land, and towns.The latitude and longitude of the observation point is 117.3233E, 40.6308N, and the altitude is 350m.
The acquisition frequency of the automatic weather station is 10s, and the output of 10min is once.The observation factors include air temperature and relative humidity (30.56m, 10.66m), and the direction is due to the north.Wind speed (30.56m, 10.66m), wind direction (30.56m), heading due north;Air pressure (installed in waterproof box);Rainfall (31.46m);The four-component radiation (30.76m) is oriented due to the south.Infrared surface temperature (30.76m), the arm is facing south, the probe is facing vertically downward;The soil temperature and humidity probe was buried 2m south of the meteorological tower. The buried depth of the soil temperature probe was 0cm, 5cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 60cm, 80cm and 100cm. The buried depth of the soil water sensor was 2cm, 5cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 60cm and 100cm.Two hot plates (2) are buried 2cm underground, one in the ground where the sun can penetrate the fruit trees, and the other in the shadow of the fruit trees.Processing and quality control of observation data :(1) ensure 144 data per day (every 10min). If data is missing, it will be marked by -6999;(2) eliminate the moments with duplicate records;(3) data that is obviously beyond the physical meaning or the range of the instrument is deleted;(4) the format of date and time is unified, and the date and time are in the same column.For example, the time is: June 10, 2010 at 10:30.
Data released by the automatic weather station include:Date/Time for the Date/Time, and the air temperature humidity observation (Ta_10. 66 m, RH_10. 66 m, Ta_30. 56 m, RH_30. 56 m) (℃, %), wind speed (Ws_10. 66 m, Ws_30. 56 m) (m/s), wind (WD) (°), pressure (Press) (hpa), precipitation (Rain) (mm), four component radiation (DR, UR, DLR, ULR, Rn) (W/m2), the surface radiation temperature (IRT_1, IRT_2) (℃),Soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2) (W/m2), multi-layer soil moisture (Ms_2cm, Ms_5cm, Ms_10cm, Ms_20cm, Ms_40cm, Ms_60cm, Ms_100cm) (%) and multi-layer soil temperature (Ts_0cm, Ts_5cm, Ts_10cm, Ts_20cm, Ts_40cm, Ts_60cm, Ts_80cm, Ts_100cm) (℃).
Please refer to Jia et al,(2012) for information of observation test or site, and Liu et al,(2013) for data processing.

background: The accurate estimation of water and heat fluxes is crucial to climate change research, water resource planning and management, and water-saving agriculture applications. Ground measurements are relatively accurate at the patch scale. However, the monitoring network for ground measurements is not sufficient for global coverage, and there is a need to upscale observations from the patch to the regional scale. The remote sensing method can acquire land surface information accurately at the regional scale, which creates new opportunities for monitoring water and heat fluxes. Over the last 20 years, evolving land surface models have been able to produce continuous temporal and spatial variations of water and heat fluxes. However, the land model output is strongly contaminated by uncertainties within the model parameters, model structures, and forcing data; this has adversely affected the development and application of land surface models. Considering these issues, developing a series of techniques combining land surface models with different types of observations is necessary. Data assimilation is one such technique and is one of the most advanced approaches to improving land surface model predictions. Surface temperature has been established to be a key factor for water and energy balance studies. Surface temperature influences the partitioning of incoming radiant energy into ground, as well as sensible and latent heat fluxes. Overestimating the surface temperature results in excessive estimates of sensible and soil heat fluxes, which can impact the boundary layer development and atmospheric dynamics. Underestimating the results has corresponding adverse effects. Although latent heat flux is mainly affected by soil moisture, surface temperature is an important parameter too.
research objective: This study developed two data assimilation strategies that combine the MODIS LST products with the Common Land Model (CLM). Strategy 1 improves water and heat flux estimates by adjusting soil temperature, while strategy 2 achieves this goal by adjusting soil moisture.
challenges: The monitoring network for ground measurements is not sufficient for global coverage, and there is a need to upscale observations from the patch to the regional scale. Overestimating the surface temperature results in excessive estimates of sensible and soil heat fluxes, which can impact the boundary layer development and atmospheric dynamics. Underestimating the results has corresponding adverse effects. The land model output is strongly contaminated by uncertainties within the model parameters, model structures, and forcing data; this has adversely affected the development and application of land surface models.
methods: The developed data assimilation system consists of a model operator for calculating the diurnal variations in water and heat fluxes, an observation operator for predicting surface temperature from model state variables, and an optimization scheme for optimizing the state variables, all of which are described below. In this study, two data assimilation strategies were developed to assimilate the MODIS LST products. Strategy 1 improves the estimation of water and heat fluxes by adjusting soil temperature, while strategy 2 adjusts the soil moisture. In this study, two different optimization algorithms were applied for the two strategies: the EnKF and SCE-UA.
dataset: The assimilation results were validated at six observation sites with different land cover types (grassland, cropland, and orchard) located in Germany, the United States, and China.
findings: Overall, the two strategies improved the estimates of surface temperature and water and heat fluxes by adjusting the soil temperature and moisture, respectively. Strategy 2 was superior to strategy 1 when using the same optimization algorithm. The EnKF algorithm performed slightly better than the SCE-UA algorithm when using the same strategy. Strategy 2 combined with the EnKF algorithm performed best for water and heat fluxes, and the reductions in RMSE values were 24.0 and 15.2 W m22 for the sensible and latent heat fluxes, respectively. For the results at the six experiment sites, the combination of strategy 2 with the EnKF algorithm achieved the most significant reductions in RMSE values. For surface temperature, the most significant reduction in the RMSE value was 4.0 K at the GuanTao site. The sensible heat flux had the most significant reduction in its RMSE value of 48.1 W m22 at the GuanTao site, and latent heat flux reduction was 27.8 W m22 at the Goodwin site.

background: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a key factor in surface flux estimations with remote sensing algorithms and/or land surface models. Originally, z0m is defined as the height where the wind speed, given by the extrapolation of the logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero. According to numerous observations, the variation range of z0m over different surfaces is large, from an order of 1.0 m over urban areas and mountainous areas, to an order of 0.1 mm or even 0.01 mm over smooth water body surfaces, ice and snow surfaces. The traditional way to calculate z0m is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, using wind profile measurements. In practical applications, especially for remote sensing models and land surface models, it is difficult to obtain z0m for a local or regional scale based only on station observations. Former researchers have proposed some parameterizations between the aerodynamic roughness length and the land surface properties [e.g., vegetation height, leaf area index (LAI), etc.], since wind turbulence is controlled by the structure and spacing of roughness elements (plants and other obstacles) on the land surface, and z0m describes the roughness characteristics of a surface.
research objective: Based on the data of the Xiaotangshan Experiment (Changping District of Beijing, China), which was conducted in 2002, 2004, and 2005 respectively, the objectives of this paper are: (1) to calculate z0m over different surfaces and analyze the directional characteristics of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces using an analytical footprint model; (2) to relate the estimated z0m over heterogeneous surfaces to roughness element characteristic factors, and present a heuristic parameterization of z0m as a reference for model parameterizations.
challenges: More data is needed for further discussions.
methods: This paper calculates z0m over several land surfaces, with 3 years of experimental data from Xiaotangshan. Individual z0m over each surface component (patch) is calculated firstly with the characteristic parameters of the roughness elements (vegetation height, leaf area index, etc.), then z0m over the whole experimental field is aggregated, using the footprint weighting method.
dataset: This experiment was carried out at the Xiaotangshan Experimental Station for Precision Agriculture (40°10′41′′N, 116°26′52′′E, 35 m above sea level) in Beijing. The observation period in 2002 was from 26 March to 23 April and the land cover was bare soil. In 2004, the experiment was carried out from 30 May to 7 July. In the southern sub-plot field, the land cover was bare soil between 30 May and 11 June, while the maize plants started emerging around 12 June. In 2005, the experiment was from 1 May to 10 June and the experimental layout was almost the same as that in 2004.
findings: The results show that z0m is direction-dependent, mainly due to the heterogeneity of the size and spatial distribution of the roughness elements inside the source area along different wind directions.

background: Sensible and latent heat fluxes are important indicators reflecting the intensity of heat and water vapor exchange between the land and atmosphere, influencing the energy balance between them, providing material, dynamic, and thermal sources for weather systems of different scales, and affecting the water cycle process between the land and atmosphere. Currently, there are many traditional methods for observing surface fluxes, such as the Eddy-Covariance system (EC), Bowen ratio-energy balance system, and aerodynamic methods. Among these, the Eddy-Covariance system is internationally recognized as the most reliable method for observing surface fluxes; however, its observation scale is relatively small, with spatial representativeness only on the order of tens to hundreds of meters. The Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS), compared to traditional Eddy-Covariance systems, can obtain average sensible heat fluxes at a regional scale (from hundreds of meters to several kilometers). Since the observation scale of LAS can better match the pixel scale of satellite imagery and the grid scale of numerical weather prediction and climate models, the observations from LAS can serve as ground truth at the pixel/grid scale for remote sensing estimation models, numerical weather prediction models, and climate models, thus optimizing and validating these models. The observation principle of LAS is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST), which, combined with the atmospheric refractive index structure parameter C2n and related meteorological data, utilizes the stability universal function fT related to the temperature structure parameter C2T to obtain the regional average sensible heat flux at the surface.
research objective: Using the LAS-related data from Guantao Station (January to December 2009) and Arou Station (January to June and October to November), the applicability of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in LAS observations was analyzed, and a quantitative assessment method for the applicability of MOST was explored.
challenges: Due to the influence of underlying surface cover types, flatness, water and thermal conditions, and weather conditions, it is difficult to achieve the ideal assumption of uniformity in practice. Currently, domestic research on atmospheric similarity theory mainly focuses on the similarity relationships of wind, temperature profiles, and turbulence variance. However, there is relatively little research on the similarity between temperature structure parameters and turbulence characteristics in scintillation methods.
methods: Before analyzing the applicability of the MOST theory to LAS data, preliminary processing of EC and LAS data is conducted. LAS, EC, and AWS data from the Guantao Station for the year 2009 (January to December) and from the Aru Station (January to June and October to November) are selected.
dataset:
Guantao Station (36°30′54″N, 115°07′39″E) is located in Hezhai Village, Guantao County, Hebei Province. Its observation site and surrounding underlying surface consist of farmland, including winter wheat, corn, and cotton, with winter wheat and corn being rotated. The growth period for winter wheat is from October to June of the following year, while corn grows from June to October, and cotton grows from May to October. This area represents a typical farmland underlying surface of the North China Plain. In the LAS source area, the area of winter wheat (corn) accounts for about 45%, while cotton accounts for about 47%. 

Arou Station (38°02′40″N, 100°27′53″E) is located in the valley area upstream of the Heihe River, and its observation site and surrounding underlying surface consist of typical alpine grassland, which is relatively flat. The vegetation height in the source area can reach 0.2 to 0.3 meters during the growing season.
findings: (1) Under unstable conditions, large-scale vortex motion, atmospheric turbulence development, and temperature scales can significantly affect the applicability of the MOST theory; (2) Two new methods for assessing the applicability of the MOST theory have been established, namely factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods, and it has been verified that these two assessment methods are reasonable and reliable.

background: For surface flux measurements, large aperture scintillometer (LAS) has become more and more popular in recent years. Compared with traditional observation techniques, it can measure surface fluxes on a larger scale (500 m to 10 km). At present, LAS observation is not common in China.
research objective: The daily and monthly variation of HLAS is analyzed. And the observation differences between eddy covariance system and LAS, need to be studied further combined with footprint model and energy unbalance of eddy covariance system observation.
challenges: There is much less agreement on the form which universal stability function fT should take. Further more, since the iteration process of HLAS can not be convergence when low wind speed and very stable conditions appearing at night, Wm \ - 5 is specified.
findings: Sensible heat flux (H) calculation with the LAS data of above measurements shows that the beam height of LAS and wind speed are sensitive factors for sensible heat flux measurement (HLAS), zero-plane displacement height is crucial unless the beam height is much larger than it, and Bowen ratio needs to be determined accurately over wet surface, while air temperature, air pressure and aerodynamic roughness length are not sensitive for HLAS. According to the observations mentioned above, LAS can measure surface fluxes both over homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a method for collecting surface flux data over a regional scale, particularly in the context of agricultural or heterogeneous landscapes?
Example.Answer: An example of such a method is the use of a Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS), which can measure surface fluxes on a larger scale (500 m to 10 km) compared to traditional systems. The LAS observation is based on Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory and can be used for regional-scale evaluations, such as in agricultural landscapes with varying land cover like winter wheat and maize.

Example.Question: What is an example of a data assimilation strategy that integrates remote sensing products with land surface models to improve water and heat flux estimates?
Example.Answer: One example is the development of two data assimilation strategies that incorporate MODIS Land Surface Temperature (LST) products with the Common Land Model (CLM). Strategy 1 adjusts soil temperature to improve water and heat flux estimates, while Strategy 2 adjusts soil moisture, both enhancing model predictions.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of how aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is calculated over heterogeneous surfaces, including any parameterization approaches used?
Example.Answer: An example can be found in the Xiaotangshan Experiment, where z0m over different surfaces was calculated using characteristic parameters of roughness elements like vegetation height and leaf area index. The aerodynamic roughness length over the entire experimental field was then aggregated using the footprint weighting method, providing insights for model parameterizations.

Definition.Question: How does the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) apply to the measurement of sensible heat flux using large aperture scintillometers (LAS)?
Definition.Answer: The Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) is used in conjunction with the large aperture scintillometer (LAS) to calculate the sensible heat flux over a region. It involves using the atmospheric refractive index structure parameter and meteorological data to derive the regional average sensible heat flux, which is important for matching the scale of satellite pixels and weather forecast models.

Comparison.Question: How do data collection methods using automatic meteorological stations compare to those using large aperture scintillometers in terms of spatial scale and applicability for regional assessments?
Comparison.Answer: Automatic meteorological stations collect data at a high temporal resolution (every 10 seconds) but are limited to a small spatial scale, providing data that is representative of the immediate area around the station. They measure a wide range of meteorological and soil variables. In contrast, large aperture scintillometers (LAS) measure surface fluxes over a larger spatial scale (500 m to 10 km), making them more suitable for regional assessments. LAS uses Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory and is effective across both homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of applying Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory to data from large aperture scintillometers differ from those faced when using data from eddy covariance systems?
Comparison.Answer: The application of Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory to LAS data faces challenges such as the need for stable conditions and the difficulty of achieving convergence during low wind speed at night. Eddy covariance systems, while recognized as reliable for surface flux measurements, are limited by their small spatial scale and have challenges related to energy imbalance and footprint modeling. Furthermore, the heterogeneity of the land surface affects the applicability of the theory differently for these two methods.

Comparison.Question: What similarities and differences exist between datasets collected from automatic meteorological stations and those from experiments like the Xiaotangshan Experiment in terms of variables measured and experimental setup?
Comparison.Answer: Datasets from automatic meteorological stations focus on continuous meteorological and soil measurements at specific heights and depths, including air temperature, humidity, wind speed and direction, pressure, precipitation, radiation, and soil temperature and moisture. In contrast, the Xiaotangshan Experiment involved calculating aerodynamic roughness length over several land surfaces using experimental data collected over multiple years, focusing on variables like vegetation height and leaf area index. The Xiaotangshan setup involved field experiments with specific periods and land cover conditions, while automatic stations provide ongoing data collection.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the challenges associated with the application of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in LAS observations, and how do different environmental conditions affect its applicability?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges associated with applying the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in LAS observations include its sensitivity to environmental conditions such as surface cover type, flatness, and weather conditions. Factors like large-scale eddies, atmospheric turbulence development, and temperature scales significantly influence MOST's applicability under unstable conditions, necessitating the use of factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods for reliable applicability assessments.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) difficult to determine for regional scales, and what approaches can be used to estimate it from surface characteristics?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Determining the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) for regional scales is challenging due to its variation range over different surfaces and the difficulty in obtaining accurate wind profile measurements. Approaches to estimate z0m involve parameterizing it through surface characteristics such as vegetation height and leaf area index, and using analytical footprint models to relate z0m to the directional characteristics and spatial distribution of roughness elements.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of integrating remote sensing data with ground measurement data in improving estimates of water and heat fluxes at a regional scale?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating remote sensing data with ground measurement data can improve estimates of water and heat fluxes by providing more accurate land surface information at the regional scale. This integration creates new opportunities for monitoring these fluxes and can help upscale observations from the patch to the regional scale. However, it also introduces challenges due to uncertainties in model parameters and structures, which need to be addressed through techniques like data assimilation.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of having a sparse monitoring network for ground measurements on the global coverage of water and heat flux data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: A sparse monitoring network for ground measurements limits the global coverage of water and heat flux data, necessitating the upscaling of observations from the patch to the regional scale. This situation underscores the need for alternative methods such as remote sensing and data assimilation to enhance the spatial and temporal coverage of flux measurements, despite the challenges posed by uncertainties in model outputs.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of using automatic meteorological stations to collect data on air temperature, humidity, and soil moisture in the specified region?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal of using automatic meteorological stations is to accurately estimate water and heat fluxes, which are crucial for climate change research, water resource planning and management, and water-saving agriculture applications.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in ensuring data quality control for an automatic meteorological station collecting multi-scale surface flux and meteorological elements?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data quality control procedure involves ensuring there are 144 data points daily (each every 10 minutes), marking missing data with -6999, removing duplicate records, deleting data that are physically meaningless or beyond the instrument's range, and unifying the format of date and time, placing them in the same column.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can one determine the applicability of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) for analyzing data from large aperture scintillometer (LAS) observations under different environmental conditions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To determine the applicability of MOST, one must analyze the data under unstable conditions where large-scale eddy motion, atmospheric turbulence development, and temperature scale significantly affect MOST applicability. Two new methods, factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods, can be established and verified for reliability.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural methods are utilized to calculate the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces using experimental data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The calculation of z0m involves using characteristic parameters of roughness elements, such as vegetation height and leaf area index, to compute z0m for each surface component. Then, the overall z0m for the experimental field is aggregated using a footprint weighting method, which takes into account directional characteristics and heterogeneity.

Enablement.Question: What methods allow for the seamless integration of multiple data assimilation strategies to enhance the estimation of water and heat fluxes in regional climate models?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of data assimilation strategies is enabled by combining remote sensing products like MODIS LST with land surface models such as the Common Land Model (CLM), using optimization algorithms like the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) and the SCE-UA to adjust soil temperature and moisture, thereby improving flux estimates.

Enablement.Question: How do technological advancements in scintillometer design enable the measurement of surface fluxes over both homogeneous and heterogeneous land surfaces?
Enablement.Answer: Advancements in scintillometer design, such as the large aperture scintillometer (LAS), enable the measurement of surface fluxes over larger areas by matching the scale of satellite pixel sizes and numerical model grids, thus providing ground-truth data for remote sensing models and climate models.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do analytical footprint models facilitate the estimation of aerodynamic roughness length over heterogeneous surfaces?
Enablement.Answer: Analytical footprint models facilitate the estimation of aerodynamic roughness length by calculating individual roughness lengths over different surface components based on roughness element characteristics, and then aggregating these using footprint weighting to account for directional dependencies.

Expectation.Question: Why could the iterative process for calculating sensible heat flux using large aperture scintillometers fail to converge under certain conditions?
Expectation.Answer: The iteration process of HLAS cannot converge when low wind speed and very stable conditions appear at night, which presents a challenge in accurately measuring sensible heat flux under these conditions.

Expectation.Question: Why might data assimilation strategies be necessary to improve the accuracy of water and heat flux estimates in land surface models?
Expectation.Answer: Data assimilation strategies are necessary because land model output is strongly contaminated by uncertainties within the model parameters, model structures, and forcing data, adversely affecting the development and application of land surface models. Combining land surface models with different types of observations, such as MODIS LST products, helps to improve predictions.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the challenges that might arise in scaling local meteorological observations to regional or global contexts, and how could these be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges in scaling local meteorological observations to regional or global contexts include the insufficient coverage of monitoring networks, the variability in land surface conditions, and the uncertainties in model parameters and structures. Addressing these challenges could involve integrating remote sensing data, developing advanced data assimilation techniques, and enhancing land surface models to improve the accuracy and applicability of observations at larger scales.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the suitability of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in estimating surface fluxes across different environmental conditions?
Judgmental.Answer: The suitability of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in estimating surface fluxes is generally strong, but it can be influenced by factors such as varying wind speeds, atmospheric stability, and surface heterogeneity. The development of new methods, like factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods, can help in providing more reliable assessments of MOST applicability in different environmental conditions.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how data assimilation techniques can improve the accuracy of land surface models.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand why large aperture scintillometers are preferred for measuring surface fluxes over traditional methods.
Assertion.Answer: Large aperture scintillometers are favored because they can measure surface fluxes over larger scales, from several hundred meters to kilometers, which aligns better with satellite pixel sizes and model grid scales. This capability allows for improved validation and optimization of remote sensing models and climate models compared to traditional methods like eddy covariance, which have smaller spatial representativeness.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide a detailed exploration of the methodologies used to upscale ground-based meteorological observations to regional scales, specifically focusing on how remote sensing methods can be integrated into this process.
Request/Directive.Answer: The process of upscaling ground-based meteorological observations involves integrating remote sensing methods to capture land surface information accurately at a regional scale. By combining land surface models with observations, particularly through data assimilation techniques, researchers can improve estimates of water and heat fluxes. The integration of MODIS LST products with models like the Common Land Model (CLM) is one example, where soil temperature and moisture are adjusted to enhance predictions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss the data assimilation strategies that improve the estimation of surface temperature and water and heat fluxes, and evaluate the effectiveness of using different optimization algorithms in this context.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data assimilation strategies involve combining MODIS LST products with land surface models to improve estimates of surface temperature and water and heat fluxes. Two strategies are used: adjusting soil temperature and adjusting soil moisture. The effectiveness of these strategies varies with the optimization algorithm used; the EnKF algorithm generally performs better than the SCE-UA algorithm. Strategy 2, which adjusts soil moisture combined with the EnKF algorithm, shows the greatest improvement in reducing RMSE values for sensible and latent heat fluxes.
